instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
hi
I detected some corrosion and liquid, I cleaned it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.18voltage
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4 Voltage
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3Voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
Do you get 12MHz at Y5110?

Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.message:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message: Check its DC voltage at least (Y5110).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
Y5110 PÄ°N3 : 0.304 VOLT    /  PIN1: 0 

The current drawn by the motherboard is 0.02. In this case, the motherboard does not turn on. I couldn't understand why you asked me if you were getting 12MHz.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
Because SMC doesn't work without clock signal.
And that seems to be the case here.
Check Y5110 traces and adjacent resistors.

On the good board, DC voltage is 1-1.2V approx...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
sorry i checked the wrong place

pin 1: 1.1 volt
pin 3 : 1.2 volt  and I checked with oscilloscope now it is 12mhz

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> : 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> : 0

There is a voltage of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.18, shouldn't it be 8.58 here? Let's light that green now please :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
Which area was affected by liquid spill?
I recommend you to reball SMC.

thanks :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message: Since I couldn't find the stencil, I put a new one. the green light is on, it does not turn orange and the device turns off after it reaches 0.75 amps. I replaced it with another one in case the SMC might be faulty, the result is the same. When I warmed up his own SMC, yesterday the green light was on, then the orange light was on, it was night here, I never continued. I tried 2 new SMCs today and the same thing happened on 2 of them. I noticed the CPU getting a little overheated during boot up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
New SMC will never work!
SMC must come from donor board; it has specific firmware...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
I was very surprised, does this apply to all models? No way to run the new SMC? Then why is it being sold? :)
Isn't there a way to send a program to smc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light not charging
threads.message:
Sometime SMC can be reprogrammed.
You can read more about rEFIt.

But is not the case here.
